Title: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Impact of Adjusted Donor Lung Weight on Primary Graft Dysfunction in Lung Transplantation

Background: Primary graft dysfunction (PGD) is a major cause of early morbidity and mortality in lung transplantation. This study investigates the relationship between adjusted donor lung weight and PGD outcomes.

Methods: In this retrospective analysis, 194 bilateral lung transplantations were performed at Sahlgrenska University Hospital, Sweden, from January 2014 to May 2021. Donor lung weights were recorded post-procurement, adjusted for body surface area, and categorized into quartiles. The primary outcome was the incidence of PGD (grades II and III) within 72 hours post-transplant. Secondary outcomes included ICU stay duration, mechanical ventilation duration, pulmonary function at discharge, and one-year mortality. Randomisation and blinding were not applicable due to the retrospective design.

Results: The incidence of PGD was significantly higher in the "high-weight" group (22.9%) compared to the "low-weight" group (8.9%) (p = 0.020). Multivariate regression identified adjusted lung weight as an independent risk factor for PGD. The "low-weight" group had shorter ICU stays (median 3 vs 5 days, p = 0.026) and higher early extubation rates (90.9% vs 83.0%, p = 0.048). No significant differences were observed in ventilation duration, spirometry values, or one-year survival.

Interpretation: Adjusted donor lung weight is an independent predictor of PGD, indicating that higher lung weights contribute to worse early post-transplant outcomes. Incorporating lung weight into donor assessment may enhance recipient management and outcomes.
